article_title: Group hopes to aid unauthorized immigrants with spinal cord injuries
article_text:
Group hopes to aid unauthorized immigrants with spinal cord injuries Members, aiding disabled people here illegally, fight for immigration reforms

Photo: Mayra Beltran, Staff Edwin Hernandez ﻿is among the beneficiaries of the Living Hope...

Guillermo De La Rosa was fixing a friend's car when it slipped off the homemade ramps, crashing down on him as he lay beneath it.

article_metadata.description: Undergoing rehabilitation at Quentin Mease Community Hospital, part of the county's Harris Health System, he met other immigrants who had suffered devastating spinal cord injuries too.  Finding themselves thrust suddenly into perhaps the most vulnerable of positions - illegally here, ineligible for health insurance, severely disabled and unable to work - they founded, in 2005, the Living Hope Wheelchair Association, a nonprofit to help others like them.  "When immigrants are working, they're visible as political targets and visible as workers," said Francisco Argüelles, the group's executive director.  Immigrants here illegally don't qualify for any federally funded public health insurance programs, including the Affordable Care Act, Medicare, and Medicaid, though they are covered for critical emergencies.  President Barack Obama's executive action, announced last month, would grant work permits to nearly 5 million immigrants - the most expansive change to the nation's fractured immigration system in three decades - but it wouldn't expand their access to health care.  In the absence of federal health care assistance, states such as California and New York have extended Medicaid benefits to certain immigrants.  [...] it felt an even crueler blow when the hospital district in 2005 changed its policies to limit how much supplies and equipment it can dispense to all of its patients upon their discharge and for how long.  Because immigrants don't qualify for other forms of health care relief, they're often left completely on their own in paying for their care unless it's in emergencies.  Bryan McLeod, a spokesman for the county's health system, said it changed its policies in 2005 to be in line with other public health care systems and "make the most effective use of its limited resources."
article_metadata.author.name: By Lomi Kriel
